title: Google SketchUp For Dummies
description:
A little while ago, I was teaching a workshop on advanced SketchUp techniques to a group of extremely bright middle and high school (or so I thought) students in Hot Springs, Arkansas. As subject matter went, I wasnÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t pulling any punches ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ we were breezing through material I wouldnÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t think of introducing to most groups of adults. At one point, a boy raised his hand to
ask a question, and I noticed he looked younger than most of the others. Squinting, I read a logo on his T-shirt that told me he was in elementary school. He shook his head, doubleclicked something, and mumbled, ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œThird.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ He was 8 years old.

SketchUp was invented back in 1999 by a couple of 3D industry veterans (or refugees, depending on your perspective) to make it easier for people to see their ideas in three dimensions. That was it, really ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ they just wanted to make a piece of software that anyone could use to build 3D models. What I saw in Arkansas makes me think they were successful.

Before it was acquired in 2006 by Google, SketchUp cost $495 a copy, and it was already a mainstay of architectsÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ and other designersÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ software toolkits. No other 3D modeler was as easy to understand as SketchUp, meaning that even senior folks (many of whom thought their CD/DVD trays were cup holders) started picking it up. These days, SketchUp is being used at home, in school, and at work by anyone with a need to represent 3D information the way itÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s meant to be represented: in 3D. Google SketchUp (as itÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s now called) is available as a free download in six languages, and is just as popular internationally as it is in North America.
